translated: Jātaka Stories
The Dukanipāta
The Daḷhavagga
The Peacock Jātaka
“The sun rises, the one-eyed king,

original: Harissavaṇṇo pathavippabhāso;🔽Taṁ taṁ namassāmi harissavaṇṇaṁ pathavippabhāsaṁ,
analyzed: harissa vaṇṇaḥ pathavi pabhāsaḥ  tam tam namassāmi hari ssavaṇṇam pathavi pabhāsa
translated: the color of a tawny horse, illuminating the earth.🔽I pay homage to you, the color of a tawny horse, illuminating the earth.
Today, protected by you, may we live through the day.
Those brahmins who are experts in the Vedas and all things,

original: Te me namo te ca maṁ pālayantu;
analyzed: te me namaḥ te ca mama pālayantu
translated: may they pay homage to me and protect me.
Homage to the Buddhas, homage to the Awakened Ones,
homage to the liberated ones, homage to their freedom.
Having made this protection,
the peacock roams in search of food.
The sun has set, the one-eyed king,

original: Harissavaṇṇo pathavippabhāso;🔽Taṁ taṁ namassāmi harissavaṇṇaṁ pathavippabhāsaṁ,
analyzed: harissa vaṇṇaḥ pathavi pabhāsaḥ  tam tam namassāmi hari ssavaṇṇam pathavi pabhāsa
translated: the color of a tawny horse, illuminating the earth.🔽I pay homage to you, the color of a tawny horse, illuminating the earth.
Today, protected by you, may we live through the night.
Those brahmins who are experts in the Vedas and all things,

original: Te me namo te ca maṁ pālayantu;
analyzed: te me namaḥ te ca mama pālayantu
translated: may they pay homage to me and protect me.
Homage to the Buddhas, homage to the Awakened Ones,
homage to the liberated ones, homage to their freedom.
Having made this protection,
the peacock makes its dwelling.”
The Peacock Jātaka is the ninth.
